Message.Title: GE engines
Message.Msg: On Saturday, the NYC787 blog provided information on the GE engine failure (now we know it has been failures, not just one). While most of the engines have been inspected, the info revealed that the problem requires frequent inspection to detect the cracks before they become a problem. And there does not seem to be an answer to why the cracks are happening. One article I read said that GE is changing the coating on the shaft and hinting that the problem was the previous coating. But that arguement does not appear to hold up. The cracks have shown up on both 747 GE engines (-2) and 787 GE engines (-1). And they appear in the same place on the shafts. Since engines are chosen by the customer and not Boeing, they can elect to switch to the Rolls Royce Trent engine but ths can throw a wrench into the delivery schedule. In any case, this is a huge problem for GE and BA should seek damages from them for any loss of revenue. But more importantly, GE needs to reveal the actual problem (ie shaft design, type of metal used in the shaft, etc) and what they will do to fix the problem.

Message.Title: Boeing shareholders " there is some kind of serious problem with the GenX engine on the 787& 747-8
Message.Msg: This now has entered the phase where it’s incumbent on GE and Boeing to come up very quickly with a very clear answer as to what the fix is, or they’re going to be hurting very badly,”Hans Weber, chief executive officer of aviation consultant Tecop International Inc., said in a telephone interview. “They’re now under real pressure.” Because of the immediate threat of multiple engine failures on a single aircraft and the availability of an appropriate inspection procedure, there is an urgent need for the FAA to act immediately,” the NTSB wrote in a letter to the agency. “There is some type of serious problem in either the design or the handling of this part,” Jim Wildey, the retired chief of the NTSB’s laboratory, said in an interview. Unlike stress fractures, which grow gradually over time, the crack detected in the GEnx engine occurred much more quickly in the steel shaft’s microscopic crystals, Wildey said. It began where threads were cut into the shaft, making it weaker than the rest of the part, he said. The GEnx is the only option on the 747-8, the latest variant of Boeing’s iconic hump-backed jumbo jet. McNerney joined General Electric in 1982. There, he held top executive positions including president and CEO of GE Aircraft Engines and GE Lighting; president of GE Asia-Pacific; president and CEO of GE Electrical Distribution and Control; executive vice president of GE Capital, one of the world's largest financial service companies; and president of GE Information Services. McNerney competed with Bob Nardelli and Jeff Immelt to succeed the retiring Jack Welch as chairman and CEO of General Electric. When Immelt won the three-way succession race, McNerney left GE (as was Welch's plan); McNerney was hired vy Boeing in On June 30, 2005. So the top Boeing employee has failed at both GE engines and at Boeing this is why the stock price since the top employee of Boeing was 65 dollars when he hired in and only $71.28 some 7 years later and has only once gone above 80 dollars for the briefest of times . On June 30 , 2005 Apple stock was priced at $36.81 Friday is was 691 that is a gain of 1777% or 100k then is 1,777,000 Friday. Boeing then to now is less than 10% for 7 years that is actually only 9.6%. for the week Boeing is down 2.21% and year to date Boeing is down 2.82% Apple is up 1.59% for the week after a big run up the previous weeks on the new phone coming out on time and on budget. And for the year apple is up 70.69% in each year apple for the last 15 years has beat Boeing each and every year by a huge margin. Any shareholder should know that the top employee gave himself a 30% compensation raise and made 18 million dollars while your share value has done nothing for 7 years.
